sec.p: We begin by writing down the full configuration interaction (FCI) Hamiltonian in the occupation number basis. We define spin orbitals as the product of a spin function (representing either spin up or spin down) and a single-electron spatial function (usually molecular orbitals produced from a Hartree-Fock calculation). For example, in the case of molecular hydrogen there are two electrons and thus, two single-electron molecular orbitals, | ψ 1〉 and | ψ 2〉. Electrons have two possible spin states, | α〉 (spin up) and | β〉 (spin down). The four spin orbitals for molecular hydrogen are therefore, | χ 0〉 = | ψ 1〉| α〉, | χ 1〉 = | ψ 1〉| β〉, | χ 2〉 = | ψ 2〉| α〉, and | χ 3〉 = | ψ 2〉| β〉.
